body: Concept ACK, this is a good check to have.

Pushed e95b5a9ca9040cab826f041ab7cf348696a15ba3 -> 2261b186ebae38362eaceeed5ac1991b578375fa
- Cherry-picked 2261b186ebae38362eaceeed5ac1991b578375fa from #22392 as e759330d003099a8acacb1e2b7da00e1f3f1d1ea
    - Modifications:
        - Use `lief.ELF.ARCH(243)` instead of 'RISCV' special value
        - Update `assertEqual` expected string in `test-symbol-check`
- Stop using `pixie` for the new ELF interpreter check

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#23212](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23212) (lint: enable mypy import checking by fanquake)
* [#22392](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22392) (scripts: use LIEF for ELF security & symbol checks by fanquake)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

I missed this before, but I think it can now be removed from the commit message of 2261b186ebae38362eaceeed5ac1991b578375fa, as only lief is used now?
```
    Code reviewers: You may see that both lief and pixie are used for
    check_ELF_interpreter. That's because at the time of writing:
      - lief does not recognize riscv64 yet (fixed by fanquake in e83f812,
        not yet in a release)
      - pixie does not know how to extract the interpreter
```

Code review ACK otherwise.

> can now be removed from the commit message

Yes, done in latest push!

Thank you
Code review ACK 6071282e0af299ebc90ebc8d1b4662a081574bf5

> Cherry-picked 2261b18 from scripts: use LIEF for ELF security & symbol checks #22392 as e759330

I've now cherry-picked this back into #22392

diff_hunk:
@@ -244,11 +259,23 @@ def check_PE_subsystem_version(filename) -> bool:
         return True
     return False
 
+def check_ELF_interpreter(filename) -> bool:
+    binary = lief.parse(filename)
+    elf = pixie.load(filename)
body: using both lief and pixie seems overkill here, please choose one :smile:

diff_hunk:
@@ -244,11 +259,23 @@ def check_PE_subsystem_version(filename) -> bool:
         return True
     return False
 
+def check_ELF_interpreter(filename) -> bool:
+    binary = lief.parse(filename)
+    elf = pixie.load(filename)
body: I would opt for `lief` as we are moving that direction #22392.

diff_hunk:
@@ -244,11 +259,23 @@ def check_PE_subsystem_version(filename) -> bool:
         return True
     return False
 
+def check_ELF_interpreter(filename) -> bool:
+    binary = lief.parse(filename)
+    elf = pixie.load(filename)
body:
I explained this in the commit message:

```
Code reviewers: You may see that both lief and pixie are used for
check_ELF_interpreter. That's because at the time of writing:
  - lief does not recognize riscv64 yet (fixed by fanquake in e83f812,
    not yet in a release)
  - pixie does not know how to extract the interpreter
```

~Let me know if I'm missing some functionality here!~

Oh! I see that fanquake's PR has a workaround for lief riscv stuff, I'll see if I can use that!

         return True
     return False
 
+def check_ELF_interpreter(filename) -> bool:
+    binary = lief.parse(filename)
+    elf = pixie.load(filename)
body: Oops, I missed that commit message, sorry.

diff_hunk:
@@ -58,10 +54,26 @@
 
 # Ignore symbols that are exported as part of every executable
 IGNORE_EXPORTS = {
-'_edata', '_end', '__end__', '_init', '__bss_start', '__bss_start__', '_bss_end__', '__bss_end__', '_fini', '_IO_stdin_used', 'stdin', 'stdout', 'stderr',
+'_edata', '_end', '__end__', '_init', '__bss_start', '__bss_start__', '_bss_end__',
+'__bss_end__', '_fini', '_IO_stdin_used', 'stdin', 'stdout', 'stderr',
 'environ', '_environ', '__environ',
 }
 
+# Expected linker-loader names can be found here:
+# https://sourceware.org/glibc/wiki/ABIList?action=recall&rev=16
+#
+# The value is either a string, or a tuple whereby:
+#     - the 0th item is the name for big-endian machines, and
+#     - the 1st item is the name for little-endian machines
+ELF_INTERPRETER_NAMES = {
body:
I've been thinking of this a bit and I'd slightly prefer to change this to:
```python
ELF_INTERPRETER_NAMES = {
    lief.ELF.ARCH.i386:    (None, "/lib/ld-linux.so.2"),
    lief.ELF.ARCH.x86_64:  (None, "/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2"),
    lief.ELF.ARCH.ARM:     (None, "/lib/ld-linux-armhf.so.3"),
    lief.ELF.ARCH.AARCH64: (None, "/lib/ld-linux-aarch64.so.1"),
    lief.ELF.ARCH.PPC64:   ("/lib64/ld64.so.1", "/lib64/ld64.so.2"),
    lief.ELF.ARCH(243):    (None, "/lib/ld-linux-riscv64-lp64d.so.1"),
}
```
Then remove the `if not isinstance(expected_interpreter, str):` below. But add a check for "None" and fail in that case.
This makes sure we do not encode any generalized information about platforms that don't exist, or at least, we don't support.
